evals.prompt: Generate release notes for v2.1.0 — we need to update the changelog and write something for our users
evals.expected_output: Both a developer CHANGELOG.md entry and user-facing release notes, derived from git history between the last tag and HEAD
expectations: Runs git log to find commits since the last tag
Produces a developer CHANGELOG.md entry grouped by category (Added, Changed, Fixed, etc.)
Produces separate user-facing release notes in plain language
Developer version includes refactors and internal changes; user version excludes them
Breaking changes appear prominently in both formats
Each format has genuinely different tone and detail level

evals.prompt: Summarize this PR for the description
evals.expected_output: A concise PR summary with changes list, file counts, and testing notes
expectations: Uses main..HEAD or detects the PR base branch
Starts with a 1-2 sentence summary of the PR purpose
Lists specific changes with file/line counts from git diff --stat
Includes testing notes
Factual tone without marketing language
Concise enough to paste directly into a PR description

evals.prompt: I need a stakeholder update — what did the engineering team ship this sprint?
evals.expected_output: An executive summary with 3-5 bullet points focused on business impact
expectations: Determines appropriate git range (last 2 weeks or since last tag)
Produces maximum 5 bullet points
Each bullet explains business impact, not technical details
Includes a risk assessment line
Skips refactors, CI changes, test additions — only impactful items
Tone is crisp and results-focused

evals.prompt: Generate a changelog for the last 3 commits
evals.expected_output: A brief developer changelog covering exactly the last 3 commits
expectations: Scopes git log to exactly 3 commits
Categorizes each commit correctly even if messages are freeform
Output is proportionally brief — no padding or filler
Still follows the grouped format (Added, Fixed, etc.)
Doesn't generate user or executive formats unless asked

evals.prompt: We're about to release — give me the full package: changelog, release notes for users, and an executive summary
evals.expected_output: All three formats generated from the same git range, clearly separated, each with distinct tone
expectations: Produces all three formats: developer, user, executive
All three cover the same commit range
Developer changelog is comprehensive and technical
User notes are plain language with no internal jargon
Executive summary is 3-5 bullets max
Breaking changes appear in all three formats
Internal-only changes (refactors, CI) appear only in developer changelog
Each format is clearly separated and labeled
